title: http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/travel/10Turku.html?ref=travel_sentence0
text: “LIFE ON A LEAF,” a whimsical yellow house that sits in a wooded park at the edge of Turku in southern Finland, is a lopsided construction with a bright red, blue and green roof and a leaf-shaped floor plan.

title: http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/travel/10Turku.html?ref=travel_sentence1
text: Inside, it’s even wackier: curved walls, windows in the shape of teardrops, and a catwalk with a tiny video screen embedded in the floor that shows an endless loop of antlike commuters rushing through Grand Central Terminal in New York.

title: http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/travel/10Turku.html?ref=travel_sentence2
text: On an unseasonably warm September morning I traveled to the Leaf house, which has become something of a local landmark, passing Turku’s harbor overlooked by pine-forested hills, then turning into a clearing in the woods.

title: http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/travel/10Turku.html?ref=travel_sentence3
text: Jan-Erik Andersson — the artist, sculptor and interior designer who, with contributions from 20 other artists, created the place, and gives tours to groups of visitors who make arrangements in advance — was waiting for me.

title: http://travel.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/travel/10Turku.html?ref=travel_sentence4
text: On the front lawn we lingered in front of his work-in-progress: a fiberglass sauna shaped like a garlic clove, one of five Finnish bathhouses that will be on display in SaunaLab, an exhibition at Turku 2011, the coming yearlong culture festival.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence0
text: “IF you can’t say something good about someone, sit right here by me,” Alice Roosevelt Longworth, a self-proclaimed “hedonist,” used to say.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence1
text: But it seems the greater pleasure comes from more temperate gossip.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence2
text: New research finds that gossiping can be good for you — as long as you have something nice to say.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence3
text: In a presentation in September, Jennifer Cole, a social psychologist, and Hannah Scrivener reported results from two related studies, both of which demonstrate that it’s in one’s self-interest to say “So-and-so’s second husband is adorable” rather than “She married that lout?”

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence4
text: In the first study, intended to measure a person’s short-term emotional reaction to gossiping, 140 men and women, primarily undergraduates, were asked to talk about a fictional person either positively or negatively.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/fashion/10Studied.html?ref=style_sentence5
text: The second study, which looked into the long-term effects of gossiping on well-being, had 160 participants, mostly female undergrads, fill out questionnaires about their tendency to gossip, their self-esteem and their perceived social support.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence0
text: Anyone driving the twists of Highway 1 between San Francisco and Los Angeles recently may have glimpsed a Toyota Prius with a curious funnel-like cylinder on the roof.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence1
text: Harder to notice was that the person at the wheel was not actually driving.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence2
text: The car is a project of Google, which has been working in secret but in plain view on vehicles that can drive themselves, using artificial-intelligence software that can sense anything near the car and mimic the decisions made by a human driver.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence3
text: With someone behind the wheel to take control if something goes awry and a technician in the passenger seat to monitor the navigation system, seven test cars have driven 1,000 miles without human intervention and more than 140,000 miles with only occasional human control.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence4
text: One even drove itself down Lombard Street in San Francisco, one of the steepest and curviest streets in the nation.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/science/10google.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence5
text: The only accident, engineers said, was when one Google car was rear-ended while stopped at a traffic light.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence0
text: To the rites of middle-age passage, some families are adding another: buying marijuana for aging parents.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence1
text: Bryan, 46, a writer who lives in Illinois, began supplying his parents about five years ago, after he told them about his own marijuana use.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence2
text: When he was growing up, he said, his parents were very strict about illegal drugs.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence3
text: “We would have grounded him,” said his mother, who is 72.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence4
text: But with age and the growing acceptance of medical marijuana, his parents were curious.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence5
text: His father had a heart ailment, his mother had dizzy spells and nausea, and both were worried about Alzheimer’s disease and cancer.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/10/us/10pot.html?src=me&ref=general_sentence6
text: They looked at some research and decided marijuana was worth a try.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence0
text: Boilerplate is safe box office, and we’ve gotten our share lately.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence1
text: So it’s great that the Guggenheim Museum is giving us the opposite in its major fall exhibition, “Chaos and Classicism: Art in France, Italy, and Germany, 1918-1936.” With its high percentage of unfamiliar names, the exhibition won’t pull crowds.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence2
text: Visitors with a stake in art-as-uplift will find the story it tells mystifying, if not perverse.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence3
text: I found the whole thing totally engrossing: a survey-style piece of investigative history with a bomb ticking away inside.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence4
text: Its narrative goes something like this: After the exhausting nightmare of World War I, Europe’s early modernist vanguard backed away from disruptive experimental styles like Cubism and Futurism.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence5
text: They retreated to traditional forms and looked back to an imagined classical past — ancient Greece, the Italian Renaissance — for images of wholeness and harmony.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence6
text: To some degree recuperative conservatism worked; it gave artists a way to keep moving when an old way seemed blocked.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/design/11chaos.html?ref=arts_sentence7
text: At the same time classicism as an ideology, with its emphasis on order, purity and exclusion, was being espoused by rising political figures intent on creating a new, lethally exclusionary social order.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence0
text: Lil Wayne’s least interesting mode is fixation. Restless and free-associative, he’s best when bouncing from one idea to the next, sticking around just long enough to master it, then splitting before boredom or self-consciousness sets in.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence1
text: “Rebirth,” the last album he released before he began serving a one-year jail sentence at Rikers Island, was his quixotic attempt at a rap-rock album, an out-of-date idea that he treated like aggressive scientific research.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence2
text: It failed less for its experimentation, which was spotty, than for the strenuousness with which he pursued it.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence3
text: From somewhere among those recording sessions, and those rumored to be slated for “Tha Carter IV,” his next album, came the songs found on “I Am Not a Human Being,” an uncentered collection of odds and ends meant to sate interest until Lil Wayne’s release from Rikers, which is expected to be early next month.

labels.name: I Am Not a Human Being

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence4
text: (He was jailed on a gun-possession charge.)

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/arts/music/11choice.html?ref=arts_sentence5
text: In a sense it’s an improvement on “Rebirth,” even if a couple of the songs bear the scars of that period, particularly the Rick Rubinesque title track, and “Popular,” which has some of the new wave sizzle he was toying with.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/economy/11currency.html?ref=business_sentence0
text: At a private dinner on Friday at the Canadian Embassy, finance officials from seven world economic powers focused on the most vexing international economic problem facing the Obama administration.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/economy/11currency.html?ref=business_sentence1
text: Over seared scallops and beef tenderloin, Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner urged his counterparts from Europe, Canada and Japan to help persuade China to let its currency, the renminbi, rise in value — a crucial element in redressing the trade imbalances that are threatening recovery around the world.

labels.name: United States Secretary of the Treasury

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/economy/11currency.html?ref=business_sentence2
text: But the next afternoon, the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund ended with a tepid statement that made only fleeting and indirect references to the simmering currency tensions.

labels.name: Annual Meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank Group

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence0
text: Worries over Internet privacy have spurred lawsuits, conspiracy theories and consumer anxiety as marketers and others invent new ways to track computer users on the Internet.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence1
text: But the alarmists have not seen anything yet.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence2
text: In the next few years, a powerful new suite of capabilities will become available to Web developers that could give marketers and advertisers access to many more details about computer users’ online activities.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence3
text: Nearly everyone who uses the Internet will face the privacy risks that come with those capabilities, which are an integral part of the Web language that will soon power the Internet: HTML 5.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence4
text: The new Web code, the fifth version of Hypertext Markup Language used to create Web pages, is already in limited use, and it promises to usher in a new era of Internet browsing within the next few years.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/business/media/11privacy.html?_r=1&hp_sentence5
text: It will make it easier for users to view multimedia content without downloading extra software; check e-mail offline; or find a favorite restaurant or shop on a smartphone.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/sports/basketball/11nets.html?ref=sports_sentence0
text: The Nets dropped into Moscow on Sunday for a one-day visit meant to raise their profile in the home country of their new owner, the Russian billionaire Mikhail D. Prokhorov.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/sports/basketball/11nets.html?ref=sports_sentence1
text: “Welcome to Russia,” Prokhorov said as he greeted his players during their first trip to a country he hopes will become a kind of second home for the team — as well as a source of wealthy sponsors.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/sports/basketball/11nets.html?ref=sports_sentence2
text: The stay was just long enough for a little practice and an exhibition in which the Nets were interspersed on the court with top players from youth leagues across Russia — some as young as 8 years old — for a light-hearted game in the arena of CSKA Moscow, the professional Russian club Prokhorov once owned.

labels.name: Alexander Gomelsky Universal Sports Hall CSKA

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/sports/basketball/11nets.html?ref=sports_sentence3
text: Prokhorov said the visit would serve as a cornerstone for future interaction between players and coaches from the Nets and young Russians, with the aim of developing basketball in Russia, where the sport is a distant third in popularity behind soccer and hockey.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/11/sports/basketball/11nets.html?ref=sports_sentence4
text: If the Nets pick up a strong Russian fan base in the process, that would be nice, too, he said.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence0
text: The short, bearded man in the tutu wanders onstage, an accordion strapped to his back like a rucksack.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence1
text: A tall dancer feigns clumsiness with a slyly graceful gawkiness that would do Buster Keaton proud, stumbling around a ladder and a chair to the delight of the audience.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence2
text: Sasha Waltz & Guests (pictured), named for its choreographer, is the house dance ensemble at Radialsystem V (Holzmarktstr, 33; radialsystem.de), a performance space that opened in 2006 in an old brick Gothic pumping station on the Spree River in Berlin.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence3
text: Even though Berliners know about the dance troupe, visitors often miss its frequently sold-out performances in the towering space of the former machine hall and boiler room of the pumping station.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence4
text: Radialsystem V, miles away from the German capital’s grand boulevard of Unter den Linden, is surrounded by a cluster of gritty nightclubs near the Ostbahnhof train station.

title: http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2010/10/10/travel/20101010-OFFBEATCULTURE-INTERACTIVE.html?ref=travel_sentence5
text: During warmer months, a casual passer-by without a ticket to the night’s performance can enjoy a cappuccino with the dance aficionados on the waterfront terrace, but the main draw is the celebrated Ms. Waltz and her dancers, interlocked in twisted, shifting embraces.
